context.text: Justice Alito has the opinion of the Court this morning in Case 10-1121, Knox versus Service Employees Independent Union.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan

context.speaker: Elena Kagan

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And this is the same question as Justice Scalia asked.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Could you give me some help on that?

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: Sure.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: And Justice Blackmun addressed this in footnote 7 of the Brock opinion that we rely on, where he says: Of course it's not just -- you know, it doesn't operate exactly in the manner because it doesn't have all the pieces, but you still make an inquiry as to whether when Congress links two provisions together and one really won't work without the other--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So what is wrong with the presumption that our law says, which is we presume that Congress would want to sever?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Wouldn't that be the simplest, most objective test?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Going past what Justice Scalia says we have done, okay, get rid of legislative intent altogether, which some of our colleagues in other contexts have promoted, and just say: Unless Congress tells us directly, it's not severable, we shouldn't sever.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: We should let them fix their problems.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You still haven't asked -- answered me why in a democracy structured like ours, where each branch does different things, why we should involve the Court in making the legislative judgment?

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Breyer
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: Give Congress a chance to actually fix the problem.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Clement--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Could I ask you one question, which is a practical question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I take as a given your answer to Justice Kennedy, you are saying let's look at it objectively and say what Congress has intended, okay?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: This is the mandate in the community, this is Titles I and II, the mandate, the community, pre-existing condition, okay?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Here's the rest of it, you know, and when I look through the rest of it, I have all kinds of stuff in there.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Roberts
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But the -- the--

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: --and that's our whole point.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --the -- the reality of the passage -- I mean, this was a piece of legislation which, there was -- had to be a concerted effort to gather enough votes so that it could be passed.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: And I suspect with a lot of these miscellaneous provisions that Justice Breyer was talking about, that was the price of the vote.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Put in the Indian health care provision and I will vote for the other 2700 pages.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Put in the black lung provision, and I'll go along with it.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Breyer
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --This -- this case is directly parallel to the Printz case, in our view.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: In that case, the Court struck down several provisions of the Brady Act, but went on to say it had no business addressing the severability of other provisions that did not apply to the people before whom--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: But--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What he's thinking of is this: I think Justice Scalia is thinking, I suspect, of -- imagine a tax which says, this tax, amount Y, goes to purpose X, which will pay for half of purpose X. The other half will come from the exchanges somehow.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That second half is unconstitutional.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Purpose X can't possibly be carried out now with only half the money.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Yes, we think that is the proper way to proceed.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Severability--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It's not a choice between someone else bringing the case and a law staying in place.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And what we're really talking about, as Justice Sotomayor started this discussion, is who is the proper party to take out what isn't infected by the Court's holding -- with all these provisions where there may be no standing, one institution clearly does have standing, and that's Congress.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And if Congress doesn't want the provisions that are not infected to stand, Congress can take care of it.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It's a question of which -- which side -- should the Court say, we're going to wreck the whole thing, or should the Court leave it to Congress?

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Roberts
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: One is the point I'm making now about justiciability, or whether the Court can properly consider it at all.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: And the second is, we think only a few provisions are inseverable from the minimum coverage provision.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: I just would like to--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Before you go, Mr. Kneedler, I'd like your answer to Justice Breyer's question.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I think you were interrupted before that--

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Yes.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Kennedy
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --The -- the fact that that's such a clause might make it easy doesn't change the point.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Article III jurisdictional problems apply to easy questions as well as -- as hard questions.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: If I could just--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But there's no Article III jurisdictional problem in Justice Alito's hypothetical, that this is a remedial exercise of the Court's power to explain the consequences of its judgment in this case.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --But -- this Court had said that one has -- has to have standing for every degree of relief that -- that is sought.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: That was in Davis, that was Los Angeles v. Lyons.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Roberts
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Here the only--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But in restraint--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --Mr. Kneedler would you please--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --Justice Kennedy?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --When you say judicial restraint, you are echoing the earlier premise that it increases the judicial power if the judiciary strikes down other provisions of the Act.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I suggest to you it might be quite the opposite.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Kagan
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: I mean, we have never suggested that we were going to say, look, this legislation was a brokered compromise and we are going to try to figure out exactly what would have happened in the complex parliamentary shenanigans that go on across the street and figure out whether they would have made a difference.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Instead, we look at the text that's actually given us.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: For some people, we look only at the text.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: It should be easy for Justice Scalia's clerks.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: I -- I think -- I think that--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't care whether it's easy for my clerks.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Roberts
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: As I said, it is a question of statutory interpretation.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Well, how is that -- what's exactly right?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It's a question of statutory interpretation; that means you have to go through every line of the statute.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I haven't heard your answer to Justice Scalia's question yet.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Well, I -- I think in this case there is an easy answer, and that is, Justice Kagan pointed out that, that the Act itself creates a sharp dividing line between the minimum coverage provision -- the package of -- of reforms: The minimum coverage provision along with the guaranteed-issue and community rating.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: That is one package that Congress deemed essential.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Kennedy
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: So if your -- the government's position is that if Medicaid expansion is struck down, the rest of the Act can operate--

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: It's -- in the past Congress has expanded Medicaid coverage without there being -- it's done it many times without there being a minimum coverage provision.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But I still don't understand where you are with the answer to Justice Alito's question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Assume that there is a, a substantial probability that the 350 billion plus 350 billion equals 7 is going to be cut in half if the individual mandate is -- is stricken.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Assume there is a significant possibility of that.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Kennedy
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: For example, the tax on high cost health plans, which the economists in the amicus brief said would cost $217 billion over 10 years?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Those are -- what Congress -- Congress did not think of those things as balancing insurance companies.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Insurance companies are participants in the market for Medicaid and -- and other things.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But you are saying we have -- we have the expertise to make the inquiry you want us to make, i.e., the guaranteed-issue, but not the expertise that Justice Alito's question suggests we must make.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Well--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I just don't understand your position.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Kagan
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: But the second problem is that, in the provision on 68A, the -- the provision that's used for calculating the subsidy, what -- what is anticipated in the provision under the -- the Act as it is now, is that you do have the floor of the income, you would -- you would take this benchmark plan, and the government would pay -- pay the difference.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: And as we talked about earlier, the benchmark plan can change for age, and -- and the provision says it can be adjusted only for age.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: So if in fact you even have such a thing as a benchmark plan anymore -- if the rates of people in poor health go up because of individual insurance underwriting, the government subsidy is not going to pay for that.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Farr, I understood that the answer that you gave to Justice Scalia was essentially that the minimum coverage provision was not the heart of the Act.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Instead, the minimum coverage provision was a tool to make the nondiscrimination provisions, community rating guaranteed-issue, work.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So if you assume that, that all the minimum coverage is is a tool to make those provisions work, then I guess I would refocus Justice Scalia's question and say, if we know that something is just a tool to make other provisions work, shouldn't that be the case in which those other provisions are severed along with the tool?

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Kagan
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: So if in fact you even have such a thing as a benchmark plan anymore -- if the rates of people in poor health go up because of individual insurance underwriting, the government subsidy is not going to pay for that.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Farr, I understood that the answer that you gave to Justice Scalia was essentially that the minimum coverage provision was not the heart of the Act.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Instead, the minimum coverage provision was a tool to make the nondiscrimination provisions, community rating guaranteed-issue, work.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: So if you assume that, that all the minimum coverage is is a tool to make those provisions work, then I guess I would refocus Justice Scalia's question and say, if we know that something is just a tool to make other provisions work, shouldn't that be the case in which those other provisions are severed along with the tool?

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: No.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: I don't think so, because there are -- there are many other tools to make the same things work.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Breyer
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: And if one -- the case that comes to mind is New York v. the United States, where the Court struck down the take title provision but left other -- two other incentives essentially in place.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: Even without the minimum coverage provision, there will be a lot of other incentives still to bring younger people into the market and to keep them in the market.

context.speaker: H. Bartow Farr, III
context.text: And if -- if my reading of the finding is correct, and that's all that Congress is saying, that this would be useful, it doesn't mean that it's impossible.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But would you -- I would just like to hear before you leave your argument, if you want to, against what Justice Scalia just said, let's assume, contrary to what you want, that the government's position is accepted by the majority of this Court.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And so we now are rid, quote, of the true "heart" of the bill.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now still there are a lot of other provisions here like the Indian Act, the Black Lung Disease, the Wellness Program, that restaurants have to have a calorie count of major menus, et cetera.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Breyer
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Elena Kagan
context.text: Mr. Clement--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: To make you feel a little better, I want to pursue this for one more minute.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: There are cases and many, of which Justice Scalia knows as well, which uses the Holly Hill, uses the same word as this statute: In the Secretary's discretion.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And in those cases this Court has said, that doesn't mean the Secretary can do anything that he or she wants, but rather, they are limited to what is not arbitrary, capricious, and abuse of discretion in interpreting statutes, in applying those statutes, et cetera.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: End of my argument; end of my question.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: We're simply saying that look, your spending power cases absolutely depend on there being a line between coercion--

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --But could you tell me--

context.speaker: Paul D. Clement
context.text: --and voluntary action.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --I don't understand your first answer to Justice Kagan.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: You don't see there being a difference between the Federal government saying we want to take care of the poor.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: States, if you do this, we'll pay 100 percent of your administrative costs.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Breyer
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The smaller what you are demanding of them, the bigger the coercion to go along.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: --The more they stand to lose.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: And -- and so -- and then it -- I'm sorry, Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I -- just before you leave that, I'd -- I'd appreciate it if you would expand a little bit on the answer to Justice Kagan's question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: For the reason, when I read the cutoff statute, which as I said has been there since 1965 unchanged, it does refer to the Secretary's discretion to keep the funding, insofar as the funding has no relationship to the failure to comply with the condition.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And as I read that, that gives the Secretary the authority to cut off all the money, but the State's refusal to accept the condition means they shouldn't have.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Scalia
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't know of any case that, where the secretary's discretion explicitly includes a certain act, we have held that, nevertheless, that act cannot be performed unless we think it reasonable.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't know any case like that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Yes, when there is just a general grant of discretion, it has to be exercised reasonably.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But maybe Justice Breyer knows such a case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Yes, I do.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Give it to me.

National Federation of Independent Busin.speaker: Justice Sotomayor
National Federation of Independent Busin.case_name: National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius
National Federation of Independent Busin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 28, 2012

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: And I think it would depend on what the circumstances were on how -- and I think trying to think about how a court would ever answer the question of whether it was coercive, it was too difficult as a practical matter for States to withdraw.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --General, I'm trying.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: --to go back to that.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Because Justice Kennedy asked you whether there is -- I think he said it's -- it's coercion if no one can be politically accountable.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: I'm not sure how that could be practically politically accountable, because almost every gift -- if the terms are attractive, it would be an unattractive political alternative to turn it down.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: Dole itself was one of those cases.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The coercion effected by the statute is a violation of state sovereignty and on this threshold question of coercion, seven Justices agree.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Three Justices, however, devise a remedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That, again, in effect, rewrites the statute and changes its design.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And in a separate opinion by Justice Ginsburg, joined by Justice Sotomayor, these two other Justices conclude that the Medicaid Expansion is valid as written but in view of the disposition of the Chief Justice, they then agree with the remedy he adopts.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This joint dissent disagrees.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: We find no judicial authority to rewrite the statute to permit this remedy.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Congress reserved the right to alter, amend or repeal any and every provision of the Medicaid Act and participating States for their part agreed to amend their Medicaid plans consistent with alterations in the federal law.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: From 1965 until 2010, States regularly conformed to amendments expanding Medicaid, sometimes quite sizably.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The 2010 expansion is different in kind the Court concludes 7-to-2.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Justice Sotomayor and I strongly disagree.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: According to the Chief Justice, the expansion was misnamed.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It did not expand Medicaid as it existed in 2010 he maintains instead Congress established a wholly new program alongside old Medicaid and coerced the States to accept new Medicaid by threatening them with loss of funds from the old program if they hold out.

context.speaker: Steven J. Wells
context.text: --by Federal law.

context.speaker: Steven J. Wells
context.text: There could be implied preemption issues, however, in that circumstance.

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: So your -- your position is if the contract for purchase is consummated in some way on premises, that's preempted?

context.speaker: Sonia Sotomayor
context.text: And so your answer to Justice Kagan and Justice Scalia is that if the purchase contract occurs before the animals arrive at the gate of the slaughterhouse, that that would not be preempted?

context.speaker: Steven J. Wells
context.text: Not be expressly preempted.

context.speaker: Steven J. Wells
